channel.title: Mac OS X on Intel
channel.description:
Hey,
I've read a couple guides on getting Mac OS X running on Intel processors, but all the guides I've read include getting a VMware .iso file or something, which I can't find. I do, however, have the OS 10.4.7 cd's that came with my brother's iMac. If I try to just pop in the cd, it says the cd is in unknown blah blah. Any way I could get those files off the cd?
If it's relevant, I have a Intel 3.20GHz processor, trying to install Mac OS X on a 40GB slave drive, so I'm not trying to dual-boot.
Also, has anyone here done this?
Thanks.

item.title: Mac OS X on Intel
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“Intern, post:20, topic:135475”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=186930.msg2704353#msg2704353 date=1236879974]
I’m wondering, is this legal? Apple somewhat forces you to buy their hardware, even if you only want to use their OS.

On the other hand, Intel forces you not to use Mac OS X.
[/quote]Most Apple computers run Intel processors thus you can use Intel with Mac OS X. Actually it’s rumored that the upcoming Mac OS X Snow Leopard will only run on Intel Macs.[/quote]
The beta’s already run on OSx86, so I doubt it…

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

I have OSx86 in multi-boot (one of the 5). It isn’t hard if you read a bit about it. insanelymac is a great place to be for that.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X on Intel
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:13, topic:135475”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=186930.msg2703920#msg2703920 date=1236832675]
Mac OSX also runs on AMD now…
[/quote]
It don’t help if you don’t have any drivers to the other stuff.[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

Apple–Intel architecture

The Apple–Intel architecture, or Mactel, is an unofficial name used for Apple Macintosh personal computers developed and manufactured by Apple Inc. that use Intel x86 processors,[not verified in body] rather than the PowerPC and Motorola 68000 ("68k") series processors used in their predecessors. With the change in architecture, a change in firmware became necessary; Apple selected the Intel-designed Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) as its comparable component to the Open Firmware used on its...

It seems as though they’ve release it. I’m not sure, the article keeps referencing how you can boot from Mac and Windows.

Read full topic

item.description:

Mac OSX also runs on AMD now…

item.title: Mac OS X on Intel
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Apple digitally sign their hardware so Mac OS X can only be run on their own hardware unless someone cracks it you wont get the proper OS other hardware.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X on Intel
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:3, topic:135475”][quote author=Intern link=topic=186930.msg2703543#msg2703543 date=1236807122]
Mac OS X won’t run on your intel computer. The operating system is designed to run with apple hardware. You would have to make modifications to your hardware or build a completely new computer from scratch. Google Hackintosh.
[/quote]
no

theres the osx86 project[/quote]Hmm thats interesting. I’ll have a look on that later.

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:10, topic:135475”]Mac OSX also runs on AMD now…[/quote]It can run in any computer with an AMD processor?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:6, topic:135475”][quote author=io9 link=topic=186930.msg2703816#msg2703816 date=1236822011]
Artists!
[/quote]
But, Mac isn’t truthfully good for graphical design. The software is pretty much cross platform now…[/quote]

People still use Macs.

It sucks because at the Art Institute of Atlanta, I’m always looking for PCs to use.

All the labs and classes for everyone in advertising and graphic design and shit are all Macs. Nice ones too.
Tons of the labs.

And then there’s 3 PC labs.

Read full topic
